USA: The Treaty of Portsmouth, negotiated by President Theodore Roosevelt, was signed, ending the Russo-Japanese War.
Tanzania: The Maji Maji Rebellion starts as a violent resistance to colonial rule in Tanganyika.
Taiwan: Population census records 2,492,784 Chinese, 82,795 "mountain people", and a total of 3,039,751 Taiwanese residents
Sweden: The personal union between Sweden and Norway is dissolved.
Russia: Russian Revolution of 1905: A strike began at the Putilov Works in St. Petersburg.

Bloody Sunday (1905): Peaceful demonstrators arrived at the Winter Palace in Saint Petersburg to present a petition to the tsar, leading was a priest named Georgi Gapon. The Imperial Guard fired on the crowd, killing around 200 and wounding 800.
Russo-Japanese War: The Russian Baltic Fleet was practically destroyed in the Battle of Tsushima, effectively ending the Russo-Japanese War in Japan's favour.
Russian Revolution of 1905: The first soviet was formed in the midst of a textile strike in Ivanovo-Voznesensk.
Russian Revolution of 1905: A mutiny occurred aboard the battleship Potemkin.
Russian Revolution of 1905: The Potemkin sailors defected to Romania.
Russo-Japanese War: The Treaty of Portsmouth was signed, ceding some Russian property and territory to Japan and ending the war.
Russian Revolution of 1905: Nicholas signed the October Manifesto, expanding civil liberties and establishing and empowering the first State Duma of the Russian Empire.
Philippine: Establishment of Naujan, Oriental Mindoro, one of the oldest towns in the province. (Act No. 1280)
Henry Clay Ide appointed as Civil Governor (1905–1906)
Malta: An electric tramway service is introduced in Malta by McCartney, McElroy & Co. Ltd., connecting Valletta, the Three Cities, and Żebbuġ and Ħamrun.
Latvia: Russian army troops opened fire on demonstrators in Riga, killing seventy-three and injuring two hundred people.
A revolution took place in the Baltic region directed primarily against German landowners and Russian autocracy.
Japan: Russo-Japanese War: The Treaty of Portsmouth was signed, ceding some Russian property and territory to Japan and ending the war. Pro-war activists have staged the Hibiya incendiary incident nevertheless.
Germany: First Moroccan Crisis: Wilhelm met with representatives of the Moroccan sultan Abdelaziz of Morocco in Tangier in support of Moroccan sovereignty.

Field marshal Alfred von Schlieffen, chief of the German General Staff, developed the Schlieffen Plan, a plan for the quick invasion and conquest of France through Belgium and the Netherlands in the event of a two-front war.
France: The 1905 French law on the separation of Church and State ended government funding of religious groups.
Canada: Alberta and Saskatchewan are partitioned out of the Northwest Territories to become the eighth and ninth provinces of Canada.
Brazil: Law no. 1452 is passed by the National Congress of Brazil, authorizing expenditure of £4,214,550 for new warship construction (£1,685,820 in 1906).
Belgium: Exposition Universelle et Internationale de Liège takes place.
First stone of the Basilica of the Sacred Heart, Brussels laid.
Heir of the Belgian Throne, Prince Philippe, Count of Flanders, dies.
Australia: Alfred Deakin return to the position of Prime Minister.
